event: peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line placed
Chryseobacterium indologenes grew from PICC line and peripheral blood cultures
antibiotics changed to ciprofloxacin and piperacillin/tazobactam
atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response
guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure
no redness or drainage around the PICC line
no signs of elevated jugular venous pressure
bilateral radial and dorsalis pedis pulses were equal and 2+ bilaterally
lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally
tachycardia with a heart rate in the 110s
heart was tachycardic, but normal rhythm without any murmurs, rubs, or gallops
electrocardiogram was significant for sinus tachycardia, normal axis, RSR′ pattern in V1, QRS duration of 90 ms, and non-specific T wave flattening in the inferolateral leads
simultaneous right and left heart catheterization
discordance of the right and left ventricular pressures
supporting the diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis
